options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: A program offered by Major League Baseball to provide pensions to Negro League players who played for two years and could document it.

options.label: C
options.text: A program offered by Major League Baseball to provide pensions to all Negro League players, regardless of how long they played.

options.label: D
options.text: A program offered by Major League Baseball to provide pensions to only the most famous Negro League players.

multiple-choice.question: What challenges did the speaker face when trying to help the Negro League players?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: He had to attend many baseball games to find the players, and many players were difficult to contact or refused to talk about their careers.

options.label: D
options.text: He had to write many letters to the players, and many players were easy to contact and willing to talk about their careers.

multiple-choice.question: Why did some Negro League players refuse to talk about their careers?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were angry about not being recognized for their achievements.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they faced segregation and racism during their careers, and it was still a painful topic for them.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were too old to remember their careers.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the speaker's efforts to help the Negro League players?

options.label: A
options.text: He was able to get pensions for many players, reunite them with their teammates, and bring baseball back into their lives.

options.label: B
options.text: He was unable to get pensions for any players, and many players remained unrecognized and unappreciated.

options.label: C
options.text: He was able to get pensions for a few players, but many players remained unrecognized and unappreciated.

options.label: D
options.text: He was unable to reunite any players with their teammates, and many players remained unrecognized and unappreciated.
